title: Typographic Political Cartoon
content:
I was sent this cartoon from Monday’s Seattle Post-Intelligencer. A typographic political cartoon is a rare breed indeed. It’s interesting that the cartoonist assumes that readers know what “sans serif” means; in my experience, this is rarely the case. [Original link](http://web.archive.org/web/20071215144335/http:/seattlepi.nwsource.com/horsey/print.asp?id=1515).

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071215144335im_/http:/typophile.com/files/cartoon20061218_5983.gif)

 [‹ Lubalin of today?](http://web.archive.org/web/20071215144335/http:/typophile.com/node/30065 "Go to previous forum topic") [typo blogs ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071215144335/http:/typophile.com/node/30157 "Go to next forum topic")
author: auricfuzz

comments.content:
Brilliant! They’ve even included Optima, Mistral, and Papyrus. ;-)

But no Friz Quadrata....

![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071215144335im_/http:/typophile.com/files/corset_4558.png)

Did I mess up and leave those typo’s in Mr. Pa-resident? Oh, so very sorry ;-P

ChrisL

I’m going to get really pissed if Papyrus keeps showing up in political reads. It’s bad enough that I hallucinate and see it when I go without sleeping, but when it shows up in political stuff I think I’m losing it.
It would be funnier (and truer to to life) if the punchline was “...Personally, Sire, I like the fonts without the pointy bits.”
Actually, I think the most realistic punchline (although not an especially funny one) would be, “... Personally, sir, they all look the same to me.”

Change the uniform to a kevlar hoodie
